English_passages: Epistle. An Epistle (greek: ejpistolhv 'epistole') is a letter. The Epistles in the Bible are such books as Romans, 1 Corinthians, 2 Corinthians, Galatians, Philippians, 1 Thessalonians, 2 Thessalonians, Philemon, 1 John, 2 John, and 3 John. The word 'epistole' occurs 24 times in the Greek New Testament.

An epistle (/ɨˈpɪsəl/ ; Greek ἐεπιστολή, epistolē, letter) is a writing directed or sent to a person or group of people, usually an elegant and formal didactic letter. The epistle genre of letter-writing was common in ancient Egypt as part of the scribal-school writing curriculum. The letters in the New Testament from Apostles to Christians are usually referred to as epistles.
